['TOURING THESSALONIKI
WITH CHILDREN
Thessaloniki’s relatively 
small size - for a city – 
makes it a particularly friendly 
place for children and offers a 
host of activities for them. 
Go on a bicycle ride 
along the town’s bike lanes, 
especially by the waterfront, 
starting from the harbour 
(see p. 17), past the White 
Tower area (see p. 24) and up 
to the Concert Hall (see p. 52) 
or visit the Theme Parks of 
the new (east) seafront [Nea 
Anatoliki Paralia] (see p. 50) 
where there are playgrounds 
Thessaloniki Wines. 
Macedonia has a long 
tradition on wine-making, 
as the district can boast 
some of the most renowned 
Greek vineyards. In the area 
surrounding the town, a wide 
range of varieties are grown 
such as Roditis, Asyrtiko, 
Malagouzia, Sauvignon 
Blanc, Chardonnay, Voignier, 
Syrah, Merlot, Grenache 
Rouge, Limnio, Mavroudi, 
Mavrotragano, Xinomavro, 
Cabernet Sauvignon, Athiri and 
Malvasia. The Wine Producers 
Association of Northern 
Greece Vineyards, under the 
trade name Wines of Northern 
Greece, realises a programme 
titled “Wine Roads of North 
Greece” (www.wineroads.gr). 
It is about an excursion taken 
to the most interesting parts 
of the viticultural zone; this is 
combined with a visit to the 
archaeological and historical 
assets of those areas, with 
countryside activities, as 
well as a visit to wineries 
and degustation. Make sure 
you visit the impressive 
Gerovassiliou Wine Museum  
in Epanomi (see p. 68 & 80). 
For more information, 
contact the Wine Roads 
of North Greece: tel: 2310 
281.617 and 2310 281.632, 
www.winesofnorthgreece.gr
121, 122 &

122']
response:
Thessaloniki is a great destination for a fun-filled family vacation. There are plenty of activities and attractions that cater to kids and families. 

One of the top recommendations is to visit the Magic Park, the biggest amusement park in Greece, which attracts children, teenagers, and grown-ups alike. It's a must-visit for kids, with its various rides, waterpools, waterslides, and different levels of difficulty. Your little ones will love the fun atmosphere and excitement of the park. 

Another great option is the WaterLand, located in the Thermi area, which offers a fun day out for families. With its waterpools, waterslides, restaurants, and mini markets, there's something for everyone. It's a great place to cool off during the summer months.

For those interested in history and culture, Thessaloniki's historic center is a great place to explore. The White Tower is a must-visit, and there are many museums and cultural institutions to discover. The Teloglion Foundation of Art is a great place to learn about Greek art and culture.

If you're looking for something more active, the Kaftanzogleio Stadium is a great place to catch a football match or take a guided tour. And for a taste of the local culture, be sure to visit the Ag. Sofia's, a beautiful church with stunning architecture.

For a fun and relaxing day out, consider visiting the beaches by the seaside suburbs and city outskirts. The beaches are perfect for swimming, sunbathing, and enjoying the summer sun.

Lastly, for a unique experience, consider visiting the WaterLand's sister attraction, the WaterPark, located in the nearby town of Ag. Sofia's. It's a great place to cool off and have fun in the sun.

In summary, Thessaloniki offers a wide range of fun activities and attractions for kids and families. From amusement parks and waterparks to historic sites and cultural institutions, there's something for everyone to enjoy. So pack your bags and get ready for a fun-filled family vacation in Thessaloniki!
reference: Thessaloniki offers fun activities for kids and families, including bicycle rides along the waterfront, visiting theme parks with playgrounds, and various games and activities for children.

ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
The quarter was created mainly 
to provide housing for the 
refugees who settled there 
in the early 20th c.; however 
traces of settlements exist 
which date as far back as the 
2nd c. AD. In the lush greenery 
of the Municipal Grove there

Further south, on a low hill, you

5th walk: 
ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
a 3,000 hectare area. Only  
a small section of the old oak 
forest remains in Kouri area 
as a result of the exploitation

Byzantine period. Today’s

systematic reforestation that

Despite the spreading of

MUST SEE:
19.1 The Zoo.
You will find it in the section

ringroad. It covers a 5.8-hectare

19.2 Forest Theatre.
[Theatro Dasous]. Within

this open-air theatre  
(with seating for 4,000)  
is a summer venue for great 
concerts given by Greek and 
foreign artists, as well as 
other cultural events.
19.3 Theatre of the Earth.', '10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.']

response: Summer open-air cinemas in Thessaloniki offer a unique experience. They take place in gardens, providing a picturesque backdrop of trees and flowers while you watch a film. The cinemas are not dubbed; instead, you can enjoy Greek subtitles while sipping on a drink or having a snack. This setting allows for a relaxed and enjoyable atmosphere, perfect for a summer evening in Thessaloniki. The open-air cinemas are a great way to experience local culture and enjoy the city's scenic beauty while doing so. You can imagine sipping a cold drink, surrounded by nature, and watching a movie under the stars. It's an Instagrammable spot, and you'll likely want to share it on social media. The unique aspect of these cinemas is that they bring the outdoors in, allowing you to enjoy the beauty of nature while still experiencing the thrill of watching a movie. It's a great way to experience the local culture and enjoy the summer weather while doing something you love. The gardens provide a serene and peaceful atmosphere, making it an ideal spot for a summer evening. You can also imagine meeting locals and fellow travelers while enjoying the cinema, adding to the overall experience. The summer open-air cinemas in Thessaloniki are a must-visit for anyone looking for a unique and memorable experience.
reference: Summer open-air cinemas offer unique experiences such as watching films in gardens while enjoying drinks and snacks, with a backdrop of trees and flowers, and using Greek subtitles instead of dubbing.

Also known as Palais des

«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '9

response: Thessaloniki's sports infrastructure plays a significant role in promoting athletic events and community engagement through its well-equipped facilities. The city has a long tradition of sports, hosting major events such as European football and basketball finals, international track and field events, and the 2004 Olympic Games. The city's sports facilities, including the Kaftanzogleio National Stadium, are modern and well-equipped, catering to various sports and providing ample space for events. Thessaloniki's sports infrastructure also fosters community engagement through its various programs and initiatives, which promote sports and physical activity among locals and visitors alike. The city's sports facilities are easily accessible, making it convenient for both locals and tourists to participate in sports activities. Furthermore, the city's sports infrastructure is also geared towards promoting athletic events, with various venues hosting events throughout the year. The city's sports culture is further enhanced by its sports teams, such as the Aris basketball team, which provides a platform for community engagement and sports enthusiasts to come together. Overall, Thessaloniki's sports infrastructure is well-developed and plays a crucial role in promoting athletic events and community engagement in the city.
reference: Thessaloniki's sports infrastructure plays a crucial role in promoting athletic events and community engagement by providing modern facilities for various sports, hosting major events, and encouraging local participation in sports activities.

central part was enlarged by

the west section there is a 
rectangular cupolaed narthex. 
The murals (14th c.) depict 
images of saints and scenes 
from the life and miracles of 
Christ. Also, at the junction of

Sts. there is a surviving 
ottoman fountain.

house, a domed 13th c. building

open to the public until 1940.

response:
The Byzantine monuments in Ano Poli are significant for several reasons. Firstly, they showcase the rich cultural heritage of Thessaloniki, which was a major Byzantine city. The monuments are a testament to the city's history and its importance as a center of Christianity during the Byzantine Empire. 

One notable monument is the Byzantine church of Agia Aikaterini, which is a complex tetrastyle inscribed cross-in-square five-domed church with an ambulatory. The church is notable for its elaborate brickwork and outstanding murals, which depict figures of saints, scenes from the Gospel, and miracles of Christ. Unfortunately, during the Ottoman Rule, the church was converted into a mosque and the murals were covered in plaster. However, during restoration works in 1947-1951, the murals were exposed again, allowing visitors to appreciate the church's beauty.

Another significant monument is the Byzantine church of the Taxiarchs, which is a 14th-century church that used to be a monastery katholikon. The church has undergone later changes, but it remains an important part of Ano Poli's cultural heritage.

The Byzantine monuments in Ano Poli are also significant because they offer a glimpse into the city's history and its interactions with different cultures, including the Ottoman Empire. The monuments are a must-visit for anyone interested in history, culture, and architecture.

For a solo traveler, visiting the Byzantine monuments in Ano Poli can be a great way to experience the local culture and history. The monuments are easily accessible and offer a unique glimpse into the city's past. With its rich cultural heritage, Ano Poli is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in Byzantine history and culture.
reference: The significance of the Byzantine monuments in Ano Poli lies in their historical and architectural value, showcasing elaborate brick-work, outstanding murals, and the evolution of religious structures from Byzantine churches to Ottoman mosques.

response:
Ano Poli, the historic area in Thessaloniki, holds significant historical importance. This charming neighborhood is home to several structures that date back to the Byzantine era, Ottoman Rule, and other periods of Greek history. 

The Agia Aikaterini church, built in the 14th century, is a prominent example of Byzantine architecture and is adorned with impressive murals depicting saints and biblical scenes. The church was later converted into a mosque during the Ottoman Rule, but was restored to its original form in the 1940s and 1950s. 

Another notable structure is the Profitis Ilias church, a late 13th to mid-14th century church that is believed to have been the main church of the Nea Moni or Moni Akapniou monastery. The church stands out due to its imposing presence and is a testament to the rich cultural heritage of the area. 

In addition to these historic structures, Ano Poli is also home to the G. Gennimatas hospital, a neoclassical building that dates back to the 19th century. The area's rich history is also reflected in its streets, such as Olympiados and Ap. Pavlou, which were originally part of the city walls and have since been transformed into major streets. 

Overall, Ano Poli is a treasure trove of historical significance, offering a glimpse into the region's complex past. The area's well-preserved architecture and cultural landmarks make it an ideal destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's rich history. 

For Instagrammable spots, Ano Poli has plenty to offer, with its picturesque streets, charming buildings, and historic landmarks making for a perfect backdrop for photos. Visitors can capture stunning shots of the Agia Aikaterini church, the Profitis Ilias church, and the G. Gennimatas hospital, among other notable structures. 

As a solo traveler, you'll find Ano Poli to be a comfortable and welcoming destination, with plenty of opportunities to interact with locals and soak up the area's unique atmosphere. The area's rich history, stunning architecture, and Instagrammable spots make it an unmissable destination for any traveler.
reference: The structures in Ano Poli hold historical significance as they include traditional buildings, the ramparts of the Acropolis, and remnants of the city's walls, reflecting the area's rich cultural heritage and history, particularly during World War II and the early 1920s.

a day trip (it’s only a short

the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park. It is a rare 
group of ecosystems with wet 
forests and meadows, rivers 
and shrubland, and the ideal 
place for outdoor activities 
(horse-riding, mountain biking, 
birdwatching, agritourism 
and so on); the Agency for 
the Management of Lakes 
Koroneia and Volvi (www.
foreaskv.gr) runs tours in

response:
You can explore the following cultural and natural attractions in the vicinity of Thessaloniki:

Natural Attractions:

*   Xylokeratia Mud-therapy Spa Centre, located 23 km north of Thessaloniki, offering mud therapy and relaxation in a serene environment.
*   Pikrolimni, a scenic area with a lake, perfect for a peaceful getaway or a spot for Instagram-worthy photos.
*   The nearby Kilkis region, known for its natural beauty and rich history, offering opportunities for hiking and exploration.

Cultural Attractions:

*   The White Tower, a historic landmark and a must-visit attraction in Thessaloniki, offering stunning views of the city.
*   The nearby Archaeological Site of the Ancient Agora of Thessaloniki, featuring ancient ruins and artifacts.
*   The city of Kilkis, with its rich history and cultural heritage, offering a glimpse into the region's past.
*   The Thessaloniki Concert Hall, a modern venue hosting various cultural events and performances throughout the year.

Other Recommendations:

*   The Forest Theatre [Theatro Dasous], a unique venue offering a blend of nature and culture.
*   The Theatre of the Earth [Theatro Gis], a historic theater hosting various performances and events.
*   The Museum of the History of the Macedonian Struggle for Independence, offering insights into the region's history and culture.

These attractions offer a mix of natural beauty, cultural heritage, and entertainment, making them perfect for a solo traveler looking to explore the surrounding area. With its rich history and natural beauty, Thessaloniki and its vicinity provide a unique and enriching experience for any traveler.
reference: In the vicinity of Thessaloniki, cultural and natural attractions include the monastic state of Mount Athos, Petralona Cave, and the Lakes Area, which is a National Park offering outdoor activities and local delicacies.

response:
The historic center showcases a blend of architectural styles, reflecting the city's rich cultural heritage. The monumental style of architecture is evident in the buildings' facades, colonnades, arcades, and porticos, combining elements from the city's Byzantine tradition with European interwar period motifs.

Upon closer inspection, you'll notice the presence of neo-colonial, Byzantine, and art deco styles. The Electra Palace hotel, built in the late 1960s, exemplifies the neo-colonial style, while the Olympion building, designed by J. Moshé, showcases a mix of modernist and Byzantine elements.

The Acheiropoiitos church, built in 1970, combines modern and traditional Macedonian architecture with references to the style of the Mount Athos monasteries. The Nedelkou Building, constructed in 1909, features a unique blend of Renaissance, Baroque, Neoclassical, and Art Nouveau elements.

As you explore the historic center, you'll also notice the presence of eclectic and art deco styles, particularly on Venizelou Street, which is lined with many interesting buildings. The Gategno-Florentin Building, built in 1925, is a notable example of architectural eclecticism.

These diverse architectural styles not only reflect the city's cultural diversity but also create a visually striking and Instagram-worthy environment. As a solo traveler, you'll appreciate the opportunity to explore and discover the unique character of each building, making your weekend getaway an unforgettable experience.
reference: The architectural styles found in the historic center include modern and traditional Macedonian architecture, elements of Mount Athos monasteries, renaissance, baroque, neoclassical, and art-nouveau.

«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '36

Thessaloniki lies in the 
centre of a wide area that is 
extremely interesting from  
an archaeological, historical 
and natural point of view; 
there are countless options for

and great natural reserves  
or to areas offering recreation

1
	
ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.

response:
Thessaloniki is a city that has seen many historical transformations, with its strategic location in the centre of a wide area that is extremely interesting from an archaeological, historical and natural point of view.

Ancient Pella, located just a few hours north of Thessaloniki, is a must-visit archaeological site. The city flourished during the reign of King Philip II, who was born there, and later became a major centre of culture and politics among the Hellenic City States. The site features exquisite mosaic floors in the buildings, which showcase the high standard of living enjoyed by the residents.

Thessaloniki itself is home to several archaeological museums, including the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, which houses a vast collection of artifacts from the city's rich history. The Museum of Byzantine Culture is also worth visiting, as it provides insight into the city's Byzantine legacy.

In addition to its rich history and cultural significance, Thessaloniki is also home to several historical landmarks, including the White Tower, which has been converted into a museum. The tower offers stunning views of the city and its surroundings.

Throughout its history, Thessaloniki has been a major cultural and economic centre, with a strategic location that has made it an attractive hub for trade and commerce. The city's cultural use over time has been shaped by its location, with influences from ancient civilizations, the Roman Empire, and the Byzantine Empire.

Overall, Thessaloniki is a city that offers a wealth of historical significance, archaeological sites, and cultural attractions. Its rich history and cultural significance make it an ideal destination for anyone interested in history, culture, and archaeology. Whether you're interested in ancient ruins, Byzantine architecture, or modern museums, Thessaloniki has something to offer.
reference: The archaeological site has historical significance as it has been used for various cultural purposes over time, including as a venue for cultural events and housing shops from the 1st to the 13th century.

reference_contexts: ['The history of Thessaloniki\t\n6\n']
response:
Thessaloniki's history is shaped by several key events that have left a lasting impact on the city. One of the most significant events was the assassination of Alexander IV, son of Alexander the Great and Roxanne, by Cassander in 310 BC. This event is commemorated in the Palace of Philip II, which is considered one of the most important constructions of the Hellenic Classical Antiquity.

Another significant event was the founding of the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki in 1997, which promotes the Sephardic legacy in the city. The museum is a testament to the rich cultural heritage of the Jewish community in Thessaloniki.

Thessaloniki's history is also marked by its association with the Byzantine legacy, which is celebrated through temporary exhibitions and cultural events. The city's strategic location on the Silk Road made it an important center for trade and commerce.

The Palace of Philip II is also home to a collection of artifacts from the Aiges necropolis, which includes archaic tombs, pit and cist tombs, and temple-shaped macedonian tombs. One of these tombs is believed to have belonged to Queen Eurydice, the mother of King Philip II.

Lastly, the city's history is also shaped by its association with the Hellenic Classical Antiquity, which is celebrated through various archaeological sites and museums. The Museum of Thessaloniki, for example, houses a collection of artifacts from the ancient city, including tools, animal bones, and a reconstruction of the place where the artifacts were found.

Overall, Thessaloniki's history is a rich tapestry of cultural, historical, and archaeological significance, shaped by key events that have left a lasting impact on the city.
reference: The context provided does not contain specific key events that shaped Thessaloniki's history.
