response:
1997 was a significant year for Thessaloniki in terms of cultural recognition. It was the year that the city was designated as the European Capital of Culture, and this designation is still celebrated today. In addition to this, the city's cinema museum was also inaugurated in 1997, marking a new era in the city's history and cultural heritage. The museum is closely related to the city's history and features exhibits on the history of Greek cinema, showcasing the city's rich cultural legacy. Furthermore, the year 1997 saw the renovation of the Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art, which is now considered one of the top luxury hotels in Greece. The museum's renovation and the city's cultural recognition in 1997 have had a lasting impact on Thessaloniki's cultural landscape, making it a city that is rich in history, culture, and art. 

The significance of 1997 can be seen in the various cultural events and exhibitions that took place in the city, including the Thessaloniki International Trade Fair, which is still held today. The city's cultural recognition in 1997 has also led to an increase in tourism, with many visitors drawn to the city's unique cultural heritage and historical landmarks. Overall, 1997 was a pivotal year for Thessaloniki, marking a new era of cultural recognition and celebration, and its legacy can still be seen in the city's cultural landscape today.
reference: The year 1997 was significant for Thessaloniki as it became the 'European Capital of Culture'.

response:
The Hamza Bey Mosque is a notable Ottoman monument with historical significance in Greece. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, a military commander of Sultan Murad II. This mosque is unique due to its peristyle, a colonnaded yard, making it the only mosque in Greece to feature this architectural element. The mosque has undergone several transformations over the years, serving as a cinema named Alkazar for many decades before undergoing renovation works. Post-renovation, it will house an exhibition of artifacts discovered during the metro excavations.

The mosque's historical importance can be attributed to its construction during the Ottoman period, reflecting the cultural and architectural influence of the time. Its distinctive peristyle design sets it apart from other Ottoman monuments in Greece. Moreover, its evolution as a venue for various activities, from a cinema to an exhibition space, highlights its adaptability and significance in the community.

The Hamza Bey Mosque is a prime example of the rich cultural heritage of Greece, showcasing the country's Ottoman legacy. As a significant historical landmark, it offers a glimpse into the past and provides a unique experience for visitors. Its inclusion in the historic center of Thessaloniki, a city known for its well-preserved Ottoman architecture, further solidifies its importance.

In summary, the Hamza Bey Mosque is a historically significant Ottoman monument in Greece, boasting a unique peristyle design and a rich cultural heritage. Its evolution as a venue for various activities has cemented its place in the city's history, making it an essential destination for those interested in exploring Thessaloniki's Ottoman past.

of the tramway (horse-drawn 
in 1893 and power-driven 
in 1907). Its first name 
was Exoches [meaning 
Countryside], on account of 
its rural character, or the Villas 
quarter, as luxury residencies 
with large gardens began 
to emerge following the 
European standards of the 
time.', '56
6th walk: 
NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE
Culture events in Thessaloniki 
were housed in this villa.
3.7  Folklife and Ethnological 
Museum of Macedonia – 
Thrace (68, Vas. Olgas Ave.)
This eclectic building (you 
will get a better view from 
Megalou Alexandrou Ave.) was 
the residence of the banker 
Jacob Modiano in the early 20th 
c. In 1913 it was bought by 
the Greek State, offered to the 
Greek Royal Family and, later on, 
it became the residence of the 
Governor General of Macedonia, 
a Military School of Medicine 
and a Seminary. In 1970 it was 
granted to the Museum and 
in 1980 the premises were 
declared a scheduled monument 
(for museum exhibits, see p. 
75). The adjacent noteworthy 
complex belongs to the Goethe 
Institut (1929).
3.8  Building at 71,  
Vas. Olgas Ave.
A once private residence, it has 
also housed a private school in 
the past and today it is a private 
nursery school and kindergarten.
3.9  Melissa Building  
(36, Vas. Olgas Ave.).
It was built in 1896 as the 
residence of a Turkish merchant 
and in 1908 it was purchased 
by the Bulgarian government.', '55
6th walk: 
NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE
Kampadakis graces its lovely 
garden. At a short distance,  
at the corner of Vas. Olgas Ave. 
and Gravias st., you will see 
the Hirsch villa (early 20th c., 
P. Arrigoni), a deserted building 
which once housed the 1st 
Police Department. Notice the 
old pillbox at the end of the 
yard – a remnant of the Civil 
War Period (1946 – 1949).
3.4  Chatzilazarou 
Residence.
Also known as Siaga residence,  
this house was built in 1890  
to plans by X. Paionidis. Next  
to it, you will see the impressive  
Marokou Residence which 
was used at earlier times 
as a boarding school; today 
it houses a Traffic Police 
Department. Opposite to it, 
there is a small garden with  
a small Roman Catholic chapel 
dedicated to the Sacred Heart 
of Jesus.
3.5  Mehmet Kapanci Villa 
(108, Vas. Olgas Ave.).
The mansion was built in 1893 
to plans by the Italian architect 
P. Arrigoni, within a 0.4 hectare 
garden, for Mehmet Kapanci,  
a Thessalonian Jewish merchant 
and banker. Following the central 
European architectural trend of 
the time, the main building is  
a three storey construction with 
elaborate interior decoration 
and has access to a tower.']

response:
The 6th walk along Nea Paralia and Vasilissis Olgas Avenue is a must-visit destination in Thessaloniki. Here are the highlights of this walk:

*   **Theme Gardens**: This walk features 12 theme gardens that cover an area of 76,657 m2. These gardens are perfect for spending leisure time, strolling, or relaxing. You'll find a variety of gardens, including the Garden of Alexander, Garden of the Afternoon Sun, Garden of Sand, and more.
*   **Garden of the Mediterranean**: This garden is a great spot to enjoy a café and take in the beautiful surroundings. You'll also find a small waterfall and a skatepark, making it an ideal place for families.
*   **Nautical Club of Thessaloniki**: This walk also features the Nautical Club of Thessaloniki, which is located within the theme gardens. You can learn about the history and culture of the club, and even take a tour.
*   **Thessaloniki Concert Hall**: This walk also passes by the Thessaloniki Concert Hall, which is located on Vas. Olgas Ave. This concert hall is a great spot to catch a live music performance or take a guided tour.
*   **Historic Buildings**: Along this walk, you'll also find several historic buildings, including the Marokou Residence and the Chatzilazarou Residence. These buildings offer a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich history and culture.

Overall, the 6th walk along Nea Paralia and Vasilissis Olgas Avenue is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the best of Thessaloniki's theme gardens, historic buildings, and cultural attractions. Whether you're a solo traveler or part of a group, this walk has something for everyone. So, come and explore the 6th walk – you won't be disappointed!

**Instagrammable Spots**: The theme gardens and the Garden of the Mediterranean offer plenty of opportunities for Instagram-worthy photos. Be sure to capture the beautiful scenery, unique garden features, and the Nautical Club of Thessaloniki's iconic building.

**Local Interaction**: This walk is a great opportunity to interact with locals and learn about their culture. You can stop by the Nautical Club of Thessaloniki and chat with the staff, or visit the local cafes and restaurants to sample the local cuisine.
reference: The highlights of the 6th walk along Nea Paralia and Vasilissis Olgas Avenue include the scenic views and the length of the walk, which is 50 units.

response:
The Christos Tsiggiridis Radio Museum holds significant historical importance in the context of radio broadcasting in the Balkans. As the museum is dedicated to the founder of the first radio station in the Balkans, it showcases the pioneering work of Chr. Tsiggiridis in establishing radio broadcasting in the region. The museum exhibits equipment used by Tsiggiridis, as well as material from the Macedonia Radio Station, providing a glimpse into the early days of radio broadcasting in the Balkans.

The museum's historical significance is further underscored by its location within the Thessaloniki International Fair grounds, which played a crucial role in the development of radio broadcasting in the region. The fair, established in 1926, was the hub for radio broadcasting in the Balkans, with the first radio station broadcasting from the fairgrounds in 1926. The museum's proximity to this historic site solidifies its importance in the region's radio broadcasting history.

The Christos Tsiggiridis Radio Museum is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in the history of radio broadcasting in the Balkans. Its exhibits provide a unique insight into the early days of radio broadcasting, and its location within the Thessaloniki International Fair grounds makes it an ideal starting point for exploring the region's radio broadcasting heritage.

In summary, the Christos Tsiggiridis Radio Museum is a historical treasure trove that showcases the pioneering work of Chr. Tsiggiridis in establishing radio broadcasting in the Balkans. Its exhibits and location make it an essential destination for anyone interested in the history of radio broadcasting in the region.
reference: The Christos Tsiggiridis Radio Museum holds historical significance as it showcases equipment used by Chr. Tsiggiridis, the founder of the first radio station in the Balkans, highlighting the early development of radio broadcasting in the region.

lie the tomb of King Philip 
II with exquisite murals and 
friezes on display as well as 
arms and his suit of armour 
decorated with gold; the 
remains of the funeral pyre;  
the gold larnax that weighs  
11 kg and contained the bones 
and the golden oak wreath 
of the dead king, decorated 
with the macedonian star (or 
Vergina Sun); the gold larnax 
of the royal wife; the cloth 
embroidered with gold threads 
which covered the two larnakes 
(chest-shaped coffins); and 
the two gold and ivory beds. 
The last part consists of 
what is believed to have 
been the tomb of Alexander 
IV, son of Alexander the 
Great and Roxanne, who was 
assassinated by Cassander in 
310 BC; a silver urn containing 
the bones of the dead person, 
framed with the ivory relief 
motifs of the funeral bed. 
In a separate room, visitors 
can watch a video where M. 
Andronikos takes them on a 
tour of the monuments. Other 
excavations in the wider area 
of the Aiges necropolis have 
unearthed archaic tombs, pit 
and cist tombs (6th and 5th c. 
BC), as well as temple-shaped 
macedonian tombs one of 
which apparently belonged  
to Queen Eurydice, the mother  
of King Philip II
Palace. It covers a 12,500 
m2 area and it used to be 
the largest and the most 
important construction (next 
to Parthenon, Athens) of the 
Hellenic Classical Antiquity. 
This two-storeyed edifice 
is presumed to be the work 
of Pytheos who was the 
architect of the Mausoleum 
of Halicarnassos [modern-day 
Bodrum, Turkey], one of the 7 
wonders of the ancient world. 
The palace’s architectural style 
is considered avant-garde for 
that time and it was built of

response: Alexander IV's tomb is believed to have been located in Vergina, Greece. It is a significant historical site, as it is associated with the royal family of Macedon and the ancient Greek city of Vergina. The tomb is notable for the gold larnax, a golden chest-shaped coffin, that weighs 11 kg and contains the bones of Alexander IV, as well as the golden oak wreath that decorated his funeral pyre. The tomb is also linked to King Philip II, Alexander's father, and his wife, who had a cist tomb in the area. The Royal Tombs of Vergina, which include Alexander IV's tomb, are considered one of the most important archaeological sites in Greece. They date back to the 4th century BC and offer a glimpse into the lives of the ancient Macedonian royal family. Visitors can see the tomb and other artifacts, including the golden larnax and the funeral pyre, in the Vergina Archaeological Museum. The tomb's historical significance is further underscored by its association with the mythological figure of Persephone, who is said to have been buried in the area. The site is a must-visit for anyone interested in ancient Greek history and culture. In Thessaloniki, Alexander IV's tomb is mentioned in the provided text as being part of the Vergina Necropolis, which is part of the larger Vergina Archaeological Site. The site is a significant cultural and historical landmark, and its preservation is essential for future generations. Overall, Alexander IV's tomb is a fascinating historical site that offers insights into the lives of the ancient Macedonian royal family and their cultural practices.
reference: The tomb of Alexander IV, son of Alexander the Great, is historically significant as it contains a silver urn with his bones and is part of the Royal Tombs of Vergina, which showcase the grandeur of Macedonian burial practices and the legacy of Alexander the Great.

of the City. The architectural 
style is a mixed one as the 
eclectic features combine

response:
The Mehmet Kapanci Villa is a three-storey mansion with elaborate interior decoration, and it has access to a tower. The villa was built in 1893 to plans by the Italian architect P. Arrigoni, within a 0.4-hectare garden, for Mehmet Kapanci, a Thessalonian Jewish merchant and banker. This architectural style is a mix of eclectic features combining neoclassical, Renaissance, Art Nouveau, and Gothic motifs. 

Historically, the villa was used as a country residence for Ahmet Kapanci, a Jewish merchant, and later as military barracks and a polyclinic. Since 1986, it houses the Municipal Art Gallery. The villa's historical significance lies in its representation of the city's cultural and architectural heritage. It is also a testament to the cultural exchange and influences between Italy and Greece during the 19th century.

Visitors can appreciate the villa's architectural features, including its mix of eclectic styles and the tower, which provide a glimpse into the city's rich cultural history. The villa's location on Vas. Olgas Ave. makes it easily accessible and Instagrammable, with its beautiful garden and impressive structure. 

Overall, the Mehmet Kapanci Villa is an important cultural landmark in Thessaloniki, offering a unique blend of architectural styles and historical significance. Its preservation and maintenance are crucial to maintaining the city's cultural heritage and providing a fascinating experience for visitors. 

For a budget-conscious solo traveler, the Mehmet Kapanci Villa offers a unique and culturally enriching experience, making it an ideal stop for sightseeing and exploring Thessaloniki's rich history. Its accessibility and Instagrammability make it an excellent choice for social media enthusiasts and those looking to immerse themselves in local culture. 

As a first-time visitor to Thessaloniki, the Mehmet Kapanci Villa provides an excellent introduction to the city's cultural and architectural heritage, offering a glimpse into the city's fascinating history and cultural influences.
reference: The Mehmet Kapanci Villa, built in 1893 by architect P. Arrigoni, features a three-storey construction with elaborate interior decoration and a tower, reflecting central European architectural trends. Historically, it housed significant figures such as Prince Nicholas and E. Venizelos, and has served various purposes including a cultural center.

3 	 \x07
WEST OF THE 
HARBOUR
The area began to grow in 
the late 19th century, after the 
demolition of the seafront city 
wall and the ensuing pulling 
down of large sections of the 
city’s west and east walls. 
The short distance to the 
harbour and the rail system 
construction were two decisive 
factors which led to large 
industrial unit installations  
in the area. In recent decades 
many of these buildings 
were changed into culture 
and entertainment venues, 
while others are scheduled 
to become sports or cultural 
centres. An example would be 
the listed building of the old 
Municipal Slaughterhouse (early 
20th c.), near the FIX factory, 
after which the entire district 
was named. 
MUST SEE:
3.1  Vilka multi purpose 
venue.
This is the old textile factory 
of Torres and Co., renamed

1988 and is now restructured 
into a space reserved for various 
events and entertainment, as it 
includes a theatre, concert halls,

in Thessaloniki.
69.', '1917:	
The biggest part of the 
town is destroyed by a fire 
that breaks out on August 
18th and lasts for 32 hours. 
Rebuilding begins following 
the designs of a special 
international architectural 
committee led by Ernest 
Hébrard, French architect and 
urban planner.
 1922-1923:	
As a result of the Asia 
Minor Catastrophe (the last 
stage of the Greco-Turkish 
War) and the agreement 
on population exchange 
between Greece and Turkey, 
Thessaloniki receives large 
numbers of Greek refugees 
from Asia Minor, though an 
incoming flow of refugees 
(from east Thrace, Pontus etc) 
had already begun in 1913. 
 1943:	
The German occupation 
forces wipe out the biggest 
part of the city’s Jewish 
population by sending them to 
concentration camps.
 1978:	
A mighty earthquake 
occurs on June 20th reaching 
6.5 on the Richter scale. 
Severe damages are inflicted 
on the town, resulting in the 
death of 49 people.
 1997:	
Thessaloniki becomes the 
“European Capital of Culture”.
 2014:	
The city is named the 
“European Youth Capital”.', '99
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
Thessaloniki has a great 
culinary tradition which has 
become an intrinsic part  
of the character and mentality  
of the locals. The city’s multi-
cultural character across the 
ages has added an indelible 
stamp on its traditional cuisine 
which includes Byzantine, 
Christian, Ottoman influences 
and elements contributed by 
the large numbers of Minor 
Asia refugees who flowed in 
the town during the 1920s, 
and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices 
of meat roasted on a spit] and 
souvlaki, patsa, a variety of 
soup, pies, Anatolian dishes 
(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed 
calamari etc).', 'It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of the archaeological site is 
covered by a large rectangular 
square [Α] with traces of 
marble paving. In the S section 
of the square lies the largest 
part of the double underground 
Cryptoporticus [covered 
passageway] [Β] which was 
most probably used as a public 
storehouse.']

The Greeks becoming the largest part of the population in Thessaloniki during the late 19th century was largely due to the demographic changes caused by the Greco-Turkish War and the subsequent population exchange between Greece and Turkey. 

The war led to the displacement of many Greeks from Asia Minor, who were forced to flee their homes and seek refuge in Thessaloniki. This influx of refugees significantly contributed to the growth of the Greek population in the city. Additionally, the population exchange agreement between Greece and Turkey in 1923 further increased the number of Greek residents in Thessaloniki, as many Greeks from Asia Minor were resettled in Greece.

These demographic changes, combined with the existing Greek community in Thessaloniki, resulted in the Greeks becoming the largest part of the population in the city during the late 19th century. The city's cultural and economic growth, facilitated by the establishment of a railway connection with Europe and Constantinople, also played a role in attracting Greeks and other immigrants to the area.

It's worth noting that the Greek community in Thessaloniki was not the only factor contributing to the city's growth. The city's strategic location, trade connections, and economic opportunities also attracted people from various backgrounds, including Minor Asia, Turkey, and other European countries. However, the demographic changes caused by the Greco-Turkish War and population exchange agreement were significant in shaping the city's population dynamics and making the Greeks the largest part of the population in Thessaloniki during the late 19th century.
reference: The establishment of a railway connection with Europe and Constantinople, along with streamlined infrastructure, contributed to the Greeks becoming the largest part of the population in Thessaloniki during the late 19th century.

1
	
ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.

response:
The lion hunting scene depicted in the Pella Archaeological Museum is significant because it represents a famous representation of a lion hunting scene from ancient Greece. This scene is a representation of the mythological story of the hero Hercules (Heracles in Greek), who was known for his twelve labors. 

The lion hunting scene is a representation of Hercules' famous labor, where he was tasked with hunting and slaying the Nemean Lion. This labor was a significant test of Hercules' strength and bravery, and the lion hunting scene is a testament to the artistic skill of the ancient Greeks in depicting mythological scenes. 

The scene is also notable for its artistic value, as it features a beautifully crafted mosaic floor with intricate details. The mosaic floor is a representation of the high standard of living enjoyed by the residents of Pella, who were known for their wealth and prosperity. 

The lion hunting scene is also significant because it provides a glimpse into the cultural and artistic values of the ancient Greeks. The scene is a representation of the importance of mythology and art in ancient Greek culture, and it demonstrates the artistic skill and creativity of the ancient Greeks. 

Overall, the lion hunting scene depicted in the Pella Archaeological Museum is a significant historical artifact that provides insight into the cultural and artistic values of ancient Greece. It is a testament to the artistic skill and creativity of the ancient Greeks, and it continues to be an important part of Greece's cultural heritage. 

In terms of Instagrammable spots, the Pella Archaeological Museum is definitely a great spot to take photos, especially of the lion hunting scene. The museum's architecture and the surrounding area are also great backdrops for photos, making it a popular destination for tourists and locals alike.
reference: The lion hunting scene depicted in the Pella Archaeological Museum holds historical significance as it represents art from the period of 325-200 BC, showcasing cultural and artistic achievements of that era.

used to cover a 4,600-hectare 
area in the 1970s with a 
depth measurement of up to 
8 m. Today however, the body 
of water and its depth depend 
on climate conditions, due to 
the intensive exploitation of 
the area’s water resources.
5.3  Nea [New] Apollonia.
The small village on the 
south side of Lake Volvi (56 
km NE of Thessaloniki) is a 
historic area, as an important 
Macedonian town used to 
exist here in the 5th c. BC. 
The area’s mineral springs 
contain hydrogen sulphide, the 
temperature measures 49ο-
50οC and waters flow into Lake 
Volvi. They are recommended 
for the treatment of many 
types of neuropathy, 
rheumatism, arthritis, skin  
and gynaecological complaints. 
There are hotels, a modern 
waterspa facility and a 
comprehensive health centre. 
In nearby Apollonia, you 
will find the Info Centre for 
the Koroneia-Volvi Wetlands, 
housing a small exhibition 
on the lake habitat and the 
species living there.
5.4  Lake Volvi.', '82
Thessaloniki lies in the 
centre of a wide area that is 
extremely interesting from  
an archaeological, historical 
and natural point of view; 
there are countless options for 
outdoor activities, relaxing and 
entertainment. For instance, 
you can combine your stay 
in town with a day excursion 
to renowned archaeological 
sites and places of historical 
interest, to fascinating towns 
and great natural reserves  
or to areas offering recreation 
or relaxation.
1
	
ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.

Houses.', 'Acropolis. Excavations have 
brought to light five towers 
that were part of the Acropolis, 
and at a short distance there 
are ruins of the 3-metre 
thick fortification walls; in 
the vicinity you will see the 
remains of house foundations 
dating to the period from the 
5th to the 1st c. BC.
2.1  Veroia.
This beautiful and historic 
town in the North of Greece  
is located 8 km NW of Vergina. 
It used to be the second most 
important town for ancient 
Macedonians, after Aiges; 
prosperity times went on 
during the Roman and the 
Byzantine period. Veroia was 
one of the places visited by 
Apostle Paul and a Podium  
was constructed in 1995  
to commemorate this event. 
In the past the town was also 
known as Little Jerusalem 
because of the numerous 
Byzantine and post-byzantine 
churches out of which more 
than 50 have survived. There 
is also a centuries-old Jewish 
presence in town; Barbouta 
(on the banks of Tripotamos

response:
Nea Apollonia is a historic area with significant historical importance dating back to the 5th century BC. As a former Macedonian town, it was an important center during the reign of King Philip II and later King Cassander. The town's mineral springs, which contain hydrogen sulphide, were highly valued for their therapeutic properties, particularly for treating neuropathy, rheumatism, and arthritis.

Visitors can explore the area's rich history by visiting the Info Centre for the Koroneia-Volvi Wetlands, which features a small exhibition on the lake habitat and the species living there. The center also offers a comprehensive health centre and modern waterspa facilities, making it an ideal destination for those seeking a relaxing and rejuvenating experience.

Nea Apollonia's historical significance extends beyond its therapeutic properties, as it was also an important center for the ancient Macedonians. Excavations have uncovered various archaeological remains, including the ruins of the 3-metre thick fortification walls and the remains of house foundations dating back to the 5th to 1st century BC.

Today, Nea Apollonia remains a popular destination for tourists and locals alike, offering a unique glimpse into the region's rich history and cultural heritage. Its proximity to Lake Volvi and the Koroneia-Volvi Wetlands makes it an ideal base for exploring the surrounding area, while its therapeutic properties and modern amenities ensure a relaxing and rejuvenating experience.

Overall, Nea Apollonia holds significant historical importance due to its role as a former Macedonian town, its mineral springs, and its well-preserved archaeological remains. Visitors can explore the area's rich history, relax in its therapeutic waters, and enjoy the scenic beauty of the surrounding area, making it an ideal destination for those seeking a unique and enriching experience.
reference: Nea Apollonia holds historical significance as an important Macedonian town that existed in the 5th century BC.
